sentence: Stocks snapped a four-week losing streak for the major market gauges following a strong batch of Q3 earning results, reassuring investors worried in recent weeks over the pace of U.S. economic growth.
Most sectors in the S&P 500 recorded gains Friday, led by shares of health care companies.

Consumer staple stocks also posted a big advance after sector bellwether Procter & Gamble ( PG ) beat analyst forecasts, while an earnings beat by Microsoft ( MSFT ), and Apple ( AAPL ) rising to an all-time high, also helped lift technology issues to a higher finish.

Consumer discretionary stocks were one of the few losing sectors today after Amazon.com missed earnings and revenue expectations in its latest quarter while also forecasting another net loss during the current three-month period.
The markets began sluggishly today after the government scaled back a reported big jump in new-home sales during August.
The Commerce Department revised downward the seasonally adjusted 504,000 annualized sales pace first reported to a more moderate 467,000 yearly sales.
That left the September number little changed, with buyers signing contracts for annualized 466,000 homes in September.
Crude oil for December delivery settled $1.08 lower at $81.01 per barrel while November natural gas was unchanged at $3.62 per 1 million BTU.
December gold rose $2.70 to $1,231.80 per ounce while December silver climbed 2 cents to $17.18 per ounce.
December copper was little changed at $3.06 per pound.

Here's where the U.S. markets stood at the end-of-day:

(+) DRIV, Agrees to be taken private by an investor group led by Siris Capital Group for $831.5 million, with DRIV shareholders receiving $26 in cash for each share they now own.
(+) BJRI, Rallies to two-year high after posting Q3 net income of $0.23 per share, topping Capital IQ consensus by $0.10 per share.
Total revenue rose 9.7% year over year to $206.5 mln, roughly in-line with estimates.

(+) ISR, MRI scan reveals 70% reduction in an inoperable tumor near the brain stem of a seven-year-old Peruvian girl following a July procedure implanting the company's Cesium-131 seed directly into the tumor.

(-) CBDE, Said its FY12 and FY13 financial statements were found to contain uncertainties over related-party transactions and mis-categorized expenses, adding they no longer can be relied upon and will need to be revised.

(-) EDMC, Announces plans to voluntarily delist its stock from the Nasdaq global select market because it no longer has at least 300 shareholders of record, also citing high cost and time needed to remain in compliance with listing requirements.

(-) LAYN, Said its liquidity at the end of Q3 rose 47.8% over Q2 levels to $65 mln, which includes cash now on hand and available borrowings under an asset-based loan facility less $25 mln that would trigger covenant restrictions.
